p: Sterols constitute the major fraction of the unsaponifiable matter in many oils. More than 40 phytosterols were identified; from them β-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol account for more than 95% of total phytosterols dietary intake [32]. They are of interest due to their antioxidant activity and beneficial impact on human health [33]. The sterol content of L. kerstingii seed oil is illustrated in Table 5. The total sterol content was 929.50 mg/kg of oil. β-Sitosterol was the major form (93%), followed by campesterol (7%). The presence of high β-sitosterol was found to limit TG polymer formation in triolein, refined canola, high oleic sunflower, and flaxseed oils heated at frying temperature [34]. This suggests that L. kerstingii seed oil could be used as frying oil.
